chapter.title: How to read this tutorial
chapter.para: This tutorial is designed as a "how to" document to get users acquainted with computational electrostatics calculations using APBS. In order to perform the provided examples, you will need the latest version of APBS (&apbsurl;). Other requirements are listed in the individual sections.

important.para: Note that many of the examples in this tutorial can also be run through the web-based Gemstone service without the need for local installations of the APBS software. More information is available in .

chapter.title: How do I get my structure ready for electrostatics calculations?
chapter.para: In order to perform electrostatics calculations on your biomolecular structure of interest, you need to provide atomic charge and radius information to APBS. Charges are used to form the biomolecular charge distribution for the Poisson-Boltzmann (PB) equation while the radii are used to construct the dielectric and ionic accessibility functions. This charge and radius information can be provided to APBS in a few different formats which are described in more detail below.

sect1.title: PQR format
sect1.para: The PQR format provides a very simple way to include parameter information by by replacing the occupancy and temperature columns of a PDB-format structure file with charge ("Q") and radius ("R") information. Unfortunately, the simplicity of this format also limits its extensibility: it can be very difficult to add new atom types and parameters in a generic format without the use of external software such as PDB2PQR. The XML parameter format described below is much easier to modify.

sect1.title: Generating PQR files from PDB files (PDB2PQR)

note.para: This tutorial was prepared using PDB2PQR 1.1.2

sect1.para:
The PDB2PQR web service and software will convert most PDB files into PQR format with some caveats:
Limited ligand support. Given the ambiguities associated with implicit solvent force field parameter development, atom types not included in standard force fields are currently not supported by PDB2PQR. We're in the process of including such support.
Inability to "repair" large regions of missing coordinates. Although PDB2PQR can fix some missing heavy atoms in sidechains, it does not currently have the (nontrivial) capability to model in large regions of missing backbone and sidechain coordinates.
PDB2PQR will also perform hydrogen bond optimization, sidechain rotamer search, limited titration state assignment, and APBS input file preparation. Please see &pdb2pqrurl; for more details.

As mentioned above, PDB2PQR is discussed in more detailed on the PDB2PQR homepage . Therefore, we will review the minimal steps required to produce a PQR file from a PDB file here. To begin, choose a server from &pdb2pqrurl;#availability.

sect2.title: Choose the PDB file to convert
sect2.para:
Either enter the 4-character PDB ID or accession number (e.g., 1FAS, 1MAH, 1LYS, etc.) or upload your own PDB file.
Note that, if you choose to enter a 4-character PDB file, PDB2PQR will process all recognizable chains of PDB file as it was deposited in the PDB (e.g., not the biological unit, any related transformations, etc.).

sect2.title: Pick a forcefield
sect2.para: For most applications, the choice is easy: PARSE. This forcefield has been optimized for implicit solvent calculation and is probably the best choice for visualization of protein electrostatics and many common types of energetic calculations for proteins. However, AMBER and CHARMM may be more appropriate if you are attempting to compare directly to simulations performed with those force fields, require nucleic acid support, are simulating ligands parameterized with those force fields, etc.
It is also possible to upload a user-defined forcefield (e.g., to define radii and charges for ligands or unusual residues). Please see the PDB2PQR documentation for more information.

sect2.title: Output naming scheme
sect2.para: This is largely irrelevant to electrostatics calculations but may be important for visualization. When in doubt, choose the "Internal naming scheme" which attempts to conform to IUPAC standards.

sect2.title: Other options
sect2.para: These options fall into two categories: how to build missing atoms (including hydrogens) onto the structure and additional output configuration.

varlistentry.term: Ensure that new atoms are not rebuilt too close to existing atoms

listitem.para: "Debump" any rebuilt atoms to remove steric clashes. This is generally a good option to include.
This rotates hydrogen torsion angles and flips ambiguous sidechain placements in an attempt to optimize the overall hydrogen bonding network. This is generally a good option to include.

varlistentry.term: Use PROPKA to assign protonation states at pH...

listitem.para: Assign titration states (for proteins) with PROPKA.
Useful if you're planing to run APBS on your own. At the very least, this generates a nice template for customization.

varlistentry.term: Add/keep chain IDs in the PQR file

listitem.para:
Unfortunately, chain IDs still baffle APBS
Sorry, we're still working on introducing this while maintaining flexibility for parsing strange PDB formats... but they can be useful for visualization.

sect2.title: Running the calculation and downloading the results
sect2.para: Hit Submit to run the calculation. Note that some options (particularly hydrogen bond network optimization and PROPKA assignment) can increase the runtime. You should get intermittent updates on the progress of your calculation from the web server.

When you download the result from the web page,
One can usually download, rather than display the file, by right-clicking or Ctrl-clicking the link. many browsers will attach a ".txt" extension to the file. This generally needs to be removed before it can be used with visualization software.

Finally, for many types of electrostatic calculations, it will be useful to remove any explicit water and unparameterized ligands from the PQR structure before proceeding. This can be done with your favorite text editor.

chapter.title: How do I visualize the electrostatic potential around my biomolecule?
chapter.para: There are a number of excellent molecular graphics programs which can be used to visualize electrostatic properties in the context of the biomolecule. Since there are far too many to review in any depth, we will focus on the 3 packages with which we are most familiar.

sect1.title: VMD
sect1.para: The VMD molecular graphics software package provides support for both the execution of APBS and the visualization of the resulting electrostatic potentials. Documentation on the APBS interface has been provided by the VMD developers at http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/plugins/apbsrun/. We will supplement this with a basic demonstration of how go from a PDB entry to a plot of structure & potential in VMD using APBS.

note.para: This tutorial was written using VMD 1.8.5.

sect2.title: Generating the PQR
sect2.para: We'll perform this example with arc repressor (PDB ID 1MYK), a DNA binding protein. The first step in the visualization process is generating a PQR file for use with VMD and APBS. Please follow the directions in to generate a PQR file for this structure.

sect2.title: Loading the PQR
sect2.para:
Load the PQR file you just created into VMD ( File New molecule... in the VMD Main window). Adjust the molecule to the desired view.
At this point you may notice (to many users' chagrin) that PDB2PQR removed the chain IDs from the structure. Sorry about this; we're trying to fix it in future releases of APBS and PDB2PQR.
Depending on the force field
Visualization seems to work best with PARSE you used in PDB2PQR, you may notice that VMD is displaying some strange bonds. When a PQR file is loaded into VMD, bond distances are inferred from the PQR radii. These radii were chosen for continuum electrostatics calculations, not visualization. Don't worry if some of the bonds appear a bit strange (hide the hydrogens if it really bothers you).

sect2.title: Running the electrostatics calculation
sect2.para:
You're now ready for electrostatics calculations.
Choose
Extensions Analysis APBS electrostatics
in the VMD Main window. A new APBS Tool window should appear.
Choose
Edit Settings...
in the APBS Tool window and set the path to your local copy of the APBS executable. Hit OK to close this window.
Select the "0" calculation from the "Individual PB calculations (ELEC):" window. Hit the Edit button. Adjust the APBS settings here as you desire. The defaults are usually fine, although it may be useful to edit the ions to adjust the ionic strength used in the calculation. Hit OK when you're done.
You're now ready to run the calculation. Hit Run APBS in the APBS Tool window. Check the VMD Console window for information about the job while it's running. When the job is finished, a "APBSRun: Load APBS Maps" window should appear. Select "Load files into top molecule" and hit OK.

sect3.title: Isocontour visualization
sect3.para: One of the most popular visualization methods is the isocontour.

listitem.para:
First, choose Graphics Representations...
from the VMD Main window.
Hit the Create Rep button and change Drawing Method to "Isosurface".
Change Draw from "Points" to "Solid Surface" and Material to "Transparent".
Note that the current isovalue is 0; change this to 1 (or 5 or 10 or whatever) depending on your personal preferences.
To continue the lonstanding tradition of electrostatic potential coloring, choose "ColorID 0" for the Coloring Method.
For the negative isocontour, hit "Create Rep" and select the newly created representation. Change the isocontour value to -1 (or 5 or 10...) and the ColorID to 1.

sect3.para: At this point, you probably have an image that looks something like this (note that I changed the surface to points to make the figure a bit cleaner): Arc repressor isocontours in VMD

sect3.title: Visualizing surface potentials
sect3.para: Another popular method of electrostatic potential visualization maps the electrostatic potential to the biomolecular surface. Before proceeding, you may want to delete the two isocontours you just created using the Delete Rep in the Graphical Representations window.

listitem.para:
Go to the Graphical Representations window ( Graphics Representations...
from the VMD Main window) and create a new representation of the molecule with the Create Rep button.

Go to the "Draw style" tab of the Graphical Representations window and change Drawing Method to "Surf"
FYI, this appears to generate a molecular or Connolly type of surface rather than the solvent-accessible or Lee-Richards surface I personally prefer for this type of visualization...
and Coloring Method to "Volume".
Go to the "Trajectory tab" of the Graphical Representations window and change the "Color Scale Data Range:" to -10 to 10 (or whatever your favorite values are).

Based on your version of VMD and your personal preferences, you might want to change the color scale for this image. Go to Graphics Colors...
in the VMD Main window and select the "Color Scale" tab from the new "Color Controls" window. The traditional coloring scheme for electrostatics is "RWB" (in the Method menu).

sect3.para: Your molecule now probably looks like this: Arc repressor surface potential in VMD

sect1.title: PyMOL
sect1.para: The PyMOL molecular graphics software package provides support for both the execution of APBS and the visualization of the resulting electrostatic potentials. We will provide a basic demonstration of how go from a PDB entry to a plot of structure & potential in PyMOL using APBS.

note.para: This tutorial was written using PyMOLX11Hybrid 0.99 on a Mac.

sect2.title: Generating the PQR
sect2.para: We'll perform this example with fasciculin-2 (PDB ID 1FAS), a snake neurotoxin which binds the negatively-charged acetylcholinesterase. Please generate the PQR file using the steps outlined in .
Load the PQR file you created into PyMOL ( File Open... ) and choose your favorite graphical representation.

sect2.title: Performing the electrostatics calcuation
sect2.para:
Go to the
Plugin APBS Tools...
to open the APBS calculation plugin.
Under the "Main" tab of the PyMOL APBS Tools window, select Use another PQR and either browse to (via the Choose Externally Generated PQR: button) or input the path to your PQR file. This step is necessary to ensure you use the radii and charges assigned by PDB2PQR.
Under the "APBS Location" tab of the PyMOL APBS Tools window, either browse to (via the APBS binary location: : button) or input the path to your local APBS binary. It is not necessary to provide a path to the APBS psize.py binary for most biomolecules.
Under the "Temporary File Locations" tab of the PyMOL APBS Tools window, customize the locations of the various temporary files created during the run. This can be useful if you want to save the generated files for later use.
Under the "Configuration" tab of the PyMOL APBS Tools window, hit the Set grid to set the grid spacings. The default values are usually sufficient for all but the most highly charged biomolecules.
Under the "Configuration" tab of the PyMOL APBS Tools window, customize the remaining parameters; the defaults are usually OK
Although I usually prefer 0.150 concentrations for the +1 and -1 ion species so electrostatic properties aren't overly exaggerated..
Under the "Configuration" tab of the PyMOL APBS Tools window, hit the Run APBS button to start the APBS calculation. Depending on the speed of your computer, this could take a few minutes. The Run APBS button will become unselected when the calcaultion is finished.

sect2.title: Visualize the electrostatic potential
sect2.para: Before proceeding with the remaining steps, you must load the electrostatic potential data into PyMOL. Under the "Visualization" tab of the PyMOL APBS Tools window, hit the Update button.

sect3.title: Electrostatic isocontours
sect3.para:
PyMOL makes this step very easy: adjust the positive and negative "Contour" fields to the desired values (usually +/-1, +/-5, or +/-10 kT/e
Note that PyMOL has a slight units error on the contour values.) and hit the Positive Isosurface and Negative Isosurface and Show buttons.
At this point, you probably have a figure that looks something like: +/- 1 kT/e electrostatic potential isocontours of FAS2 in PyMOL

sect3.title: Surface potentials
sect3.para: If you haven't already, hide the isocontours by hitting Positive Isosurface and Negative Isosurface and Hide buttons.

The surface potential is also straightforward to visualize. Set the "Low" and "High" values to the desired values (usually +/-1, +/-5, or +/-10 kT/e) at which the surface colors are clamped at red (-) or blue (+). Check the "Solvent accessible surface" and "Color by potential on sol. acc. surf." buttons to plot the potential on the solvent-accessible (probe-inflated or Lee-Richards) surface
In my opinion, the solvent-accessible surface tends to reveal more global features of the surface potential. Tighter surfaces (e.g., van der Waals and molecular or Connolly surfaces) tend to simply map atomic surface onto the biomolecular surface. . Hit the "Molecular Surface" Show button to load the surface potential. +/- 5 kT/e electrostatic surface potential of FAS2 in PyMOL

sect1.title: PMV
sect1.para: The PMV molecular graphics software package provides support for both the execution of APBS and the visualization of the resulting electrostatic potentials. Documentation on the APBS interface has been provided by the PMV developers at http://msltools.scripps.edu/documentation/tutorial/molecular-electrostatics We will supplement this with a basic demonstration of how go from a PDB entry to a plot of structure & potential in PMV using APBS.

note.para: This tutorial was written using PMV 1.4.3.

sect2.title: Generating the PQR
sect2.para: We'll perform this example with calmodulin (PDB ID 1CFD), a calcium binding protein. The first step in the visualization process is generating a PQR file for use with PMV and APBS. Please follow the directions in to generate a PQR file for this structure.
sect2.note:
PMV has built-in PDB2PQR support; you can also generate PQRs on-the-fly from within PMV via the
Compute Electrostatics sub-menu.
sect2.para: Load the PQR you created into PMV ( File Read Molecule ) and choose your favorite representation ( Display ).

sect2.title: Performing the electrostatics calculation
sect2.para: Go to the Compute Electrostatics Compute Potential Using APBS menu. APBS is bundled with PMV; this calculation should work without any addition configuration.

Additional settings for custom electrostatics calculations are available under the Compute Electrostatics sub-menu. In particular, Compute Electrostatics Preferences
allows users to configure settings for custom APBS and PDB2PQR paths and behaviors (force fields, etc.). Additionally, Compute Electrostatics Setup
allows users to customize the invocation of APBS by setting ion concentrations, grid spacings, etc. Many of these options are self-explanatory and/or described in more detail in the APBS User Manual. For most visualization applications, the default settings should be appropriate.

sect3.title: Surface potentials
sect3.para:
The surface potential can be displayed from the
Compute Electrostatics Map Potential to Surface
menu item. PMV uses a very interesting method for plotting the potential. In particular, it maps the potential at some distance away from the surface to the molecular surface. This has the advantages of the "global" electrostatic properties from the solvent accessible surface potential maps while preserving the shape information provided by the molecular surface. The distance from the surface can be controlled by the "Distance from surface" dial in the PMV Map Potential to Surface window.

Can I run APBS via the web? (Gemstone)
chapter.para: Yes, you can run APBS via the web, thanks to the Gemstone service. This section demonstrates how Gemstone can be used to perform most APBS calculations commonly done through the command-line interface. Better yet, it allows you to use NBCR's resources instead of your own!

sect1.title: Getting Gemstone
sect1.para: You need to download and install the Gemstone extension for the Firefox web browser from http://gemstone.mozdev.org before starting this tutorial.

sect1.title: Preparing a structure with PDB2PQR
sect1.para: We'll start by preparing a structure with PDB2PQR. First, you need to download a PDB file from the Protein Data Bank. For the purposes of this example, we'll use 1FAS in PDB format (download directly here).

Open the Gemstone interface through the Firefox menu Tools Gemstone . Select the PDB2PQR application through the Gemstone menu Utils PDB2PQR on the righthand side of the Gemstone screen. Select the PDB file you just downloaded and any other options for PDB2PQR of interest. Your screen should look something like: Gemstone PDB2PQR calculation
Go ahead and "Run" the Gemstone calculation, check the stdOut and stdErr for any warning messages, and download the resulting PQR file.

sect1.title: Perform an electrostatics calculation with APBS
sect1.para:
We're now ready to perform an APBS calculation of the 1FAS electrostatic potential through Gemstone. Open the
Chemistry Apbs
menu on the righthand side of the Gemstone screen. We'll step through each of the input tabs in the middle pane in the following sections.

sect2.title: Calculation
sect2.para: Move to the Calculation tab in the middle pane.
Most of the "Mathematics" settings can be left as-is; however, feel free to play with the discretization and surface definitions to see how it affects your results.
Under "Molecules", load the 1FAS PQR file you just prepared in the previous section.
Don't select anything under "Energy and Force" for this calculation.
At this point, your screen should look something like this: Gemstone APBS/Calculation screen

sect2.title: Grid
sect2.para: Next, move to the Grid tab in the middle pane.
Under "General", enter 97 for X, Y, and Z "Grid points".
Under "Coarse Grid", choose 100 for all X, Y, and Z "Lengths". Center the mesh on the molecule.
Under "Fine Grid", choose 80 for all X, Y, and Z "Lengths". Center the mesh on the molecule.
Leave the "Parallel Execution" alone for this calculation.
At this point, your screen should look something like this: Gemstone APBS/Grid screen

sect2.title: Physics
sect2.para: Next, move to the Physics tab in the middle pane.
Choose any values you like here; the defaults should be fine for most visualization calculations.
At this point, your screen should look something like this: Gemstone APBS/Physics screen

sect2.title: File I/O
sect2.para: Next, move to the File I/O tab in the middle pane.
Unless you have other properties you wan to visualize, you can leave these settings as-is.
At this point, your screen should look something like this: Gemstone APBS/File I/O screen

sect2.title: Running the calculation
sect2.para:
Finally, return to the Calculation tab and select "Run APBS". After a while, the results will appear under the Output tab in the middle pane. When the run is complete, you should see something like this: Gemstone APBS/Calculation screen (run complete)
In particular, you should have the option to save the potential file calculated in this APBS run.

sect2.title: Other calculations
sect2.para: Nearly all of the examples in this tutorial can also be performed with Gemstone. Furthermore, input files can be uploaded to use Gemstone as a "portal" to web services at other institutions.

chapter.title: More examples...
chapter.para: In addition to the relatively simple applications presented here, there are a number of additional examples distributed with the APBS software package (&apbsurl;) which include ionization energies, protein-protein interactions, parallel calculations, etc.

chapter.para: Please visit the APBS-users mailing list. After you've looked for the answer to your question in the archive, please post it to the mailing list.
